title: How to Convert an AutoCAD File to a PDF

steps.title: Open Options.
steps.content: Open Options . You can find it by pressing the stylized " A " for AutoCAD in the top left corner of your screen and then clicking Options . Once you set it up, a PDF will be created for each layout when you save a file.

steps.title: Click the Plot and Publish tab.
steps.content: Click the Plot and Publish tab. It's in the line of tabs with Files and Profiles .

steps.title: Click Automatic Publish Settings.
steps.content: Click Automatic Publish Settings . You'll find this at the very bottom of your screen in the Auto Publish section.

steps.title: Set the format to "PDF."
steps.content: Set the format to "PDF." You'll see this under the General DWF/PDF Options header. More options are available, including layout choices and multiple sheets per document.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . This will close the window. You will need to click OK again to close the Options window. Once you have this configured, open a project in AutoCAD, select a layer (you can select multiple layers by holding down Ctrl as you click your mouse), and click Save in the Quick Access Toolbar. You'll see a notification as it's saving and creating a PDF version. Any files with the same name will be overwritten.

steps.title: Select the layer(s) you want to export to a PDF.
steps.content: Select the layer(s) you want to export to a PDF. If you hold down Ctrl and click, you can select multiple layers.

steps.title: Click the Output tab.
steps.content: Click the Output tab. It's at the top of your screen with Home and Collaborate .

steps.title: Click Export.
steps.content: Click Export . You'll see this in the "Export to DWF/PDF" section, and clicking it prompts more options to drop down.

steps.title: Click PDF.
steps.content: Click PDF . This opens your File Explorer so you can choose options to save the file as a PDF.

steps.title: Choose how to save the PDF and click Save.
steps.content: Choose how to save the PDF and click Save . You can give the file a name and select a location to save it in. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Click the Layout tab.
steps.content: Click the Layout tab. It's near the bottom-left corner of the drawing area. [2] X Research source This method will save a single-layout drawing to a 1-page PDF file.

steps.title: Click the Output tab.
steps.content: Click the Output tab. It's at the top of the screen.

steps.title: Click Plot.
steps.content: Click Plot . It's on the Plot panel at the top of AutoCAD.

steps.title: Select a PDF preset.
steps.content: Select a PDF preset. The options are listed in the Printer/Plotter section in the Name menu. There are several PDF options from which to choose, each optimized for different purposes. For example, if you want your PDF to be optimized for high-quality printing, you'd choose AutoCAD PDF (High Quality Print).pc3 . [3] X Research source

steps.title: Select your preferences.
steps.content: Select your preferences. Double-check the plot area, plot scale, orientation, and paper size that were automatically generated, and make any changes as necessary.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . It's at the bottom-center part of the window.

steps.title: Select a file name and location.
steps.content: Select a file name and location. Choose the folder in which you want to save the PDF file, and enter a file name for the resulting file.

steps.title: Click Save.
steps.content: Click Save . This saves your new PDF file to the selected folder.

steps.title: Select the layout tabs you want to export.
steps.content: Select the layout tabs you want to export. To select multiple tabs, hold down the Ctrl key as you click each layout tab at the bottom of AutoCAD. [4] X Research source Using this method, you'll have the option to save each layout as individual PDFs or combine them into a multi-page PDF.

steps.title: Right-click the selection and select Publish Selected Layouts.
steps.content: Right-click the selection and select Publish Selected Layouts . This opens the Publish dialog box.

steps.title: Select PDF from the "Publish To" menu.
steps.content: Select PDF from the "Publish To" menu.

steps.title: Select a PDF preset.
steps.content: Select a PDF preset. You'll need to choose a preset from the PDF preset menu. There are several PDF options from which to choose, each optimized for different purposes. For example, if you want your PDF to be optimized for high-quality printing, you'd choose AutoCAD PDF (Web and Mobile).pc3 to create a smaller file optimized for the internet and/or small screens.

steps.title: Click the Publish Options button.
steps.content: Click the Publish Options button. Now you can choose whether to create a multi-sheet PDF file containing all layouts or to create individual PDFs for each layout.

steps.title: Choose how to create your PDF(s).
steps.content: Choose how to create your PDF(s). Select Multi-sheet file to create one PDF file with separate pages for each layout. If you'd rather create individual PDFs for each layout, remove the checkmark from "Multi-sheet file."

steps.title: Adjust your other settings and click OK.
steps.content: Adjust your other settings and click OK . Double-check the plot area, plot scale, orientation, and paper size that were automatically generated, and make any changes as necessary.

steps.title: Click Publish.
steps.content: Click Publish . This will create your PDF file(s) based on your criteria. You will be prompted to select a saving location for the output file(s).

steps.title: Go to cloudconvert.com/dwg-to-pdf in a web browser.
steps.content: Go to cloudconvert.com/dwg-to-pdf in a web browser. If you don't have AutoCAD on your computer, try using an online DWG to PDF converter like this one from CloudConvert. This method requires uploading your drawing file to a third-party server, so avoid using this if your drawing contains private information. If you want to convert all layouts in the file, a multiple-page PDF will be created.

steps.title: Click Select File.
steps.content: Click Select File . It's the red button near the center of the page.

steps.title: Select your DWG file and click Open.
steps.content: Select your DWG file and click Open . This adds the file name to the page.

steps.title: Click the wrench to set your conversion preferences (optional).
steps.content: Click the wrench to set your conversion preferences (optional). The wrench button appears next to the file name. Here you can specify your preferred settings, such as whether you want to convert all layouts in the file, whether to Auto-Zoom to fit the page, and the option to set your height and width output in pixels.

steps.title: Click the Convert button.
steps.content: Click the Convert button. It's in the bottom-right area of the page. This uploads the file and starts the conversion process. When the conversion is complete, you'll be prompted to download the file.

steps.title: Click the green Download button.
steps.content: Click the green Download button. It's at the bottom-right corner. This downloads the drawing as a PDF file.
